This Chapter

For the purposes of this Chapter, a drug shall be deemed to be misbranded— (a) if it is so coloured, coated, powdered or polished that damage is concealed or if it is made to appear of better or greater therapeutic value than it really is; or (b) if it is not labelled in the prescribed manner; or (c) if its label or container or anything accompanying the drug bears any statement, design or device which makes any false claim for the drug or which is false or misleading in any particular.
For the purposes of this Chapter, a drug shall be deemed to be adulterated,— (a) if it consists, in whole or in part, of any filthy, putrid or decomposed substance.

The scope applies only for section 18, and it excludes a drug or cosmetic from being deemed misbranded, adulterated, spurious, or below standard quality based on the following conditions: (a) addition of innocuous substances required for manufacture or preparation as an article of commerce in a state fit for carriage or consumption, not to increase bulk, weight, or measure or conceal inferior quality or other defects; (b) unavoidable intermixture of extraneous substance during the process of manufacture, preparation, or conveyance.
A person, not being the manufacturer of a drug or cosmetic or his agent for the distribution thereof, shall not be liable for a contravention of section 18

A person shall not be liable for a contravention of section 18 if he proves— (a) that he acquired the drug or cosmetic from a duly licensed manufacturer, distributor or dealer thereof; (b) that he did not know and could not, with reasonable diligence, have ascertained that the drug or cosmetic in any way contravened the provisions of that section; and (c) that the drug or cosmetic, while in his possession, was properly stored and remained in the same state as when he acquired it.
